user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_dir_close:
```c
int lfs_dir_close(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_dir_t *dir) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_dir_close(%p, %p)", (void*)lfs, (void*)dir);

    err = lfs_dir_close_(lfs, dir);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_dir_close -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_dir_close:
static int lfs_dir_close_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_dir_t *dir) {
    // remove from list of mdirs
    lfs_mlist_remove(lfs, (struct lfs_mlist *)dir);

    return 0;
}
...
static void lfs_mlist_remove(lfs_t *lfs, struct lfs_mlist *mlist) {
    for (struct lfs_mlist **p = &lfs->mlist; *p; p = &(*p)->next) {
        if (*p == mlist) {
            *p = (*p)->next;
            break;
        }
    }
}
...
#define LFS_LOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg,0)
...
#define LFS_UNLOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg)
...
#define LFS_TRACE(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
typedef struct lfs {
    lfs_cache_t rcache;
    lfs_cache_t pcache;

    lfs_block_t root[2];
    struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    } *mlist;
    uint32_t seed;

    lfs_gstate_t gstate;
    lfs_gstate_t gdisk;
    lfs_gstate_t gdelta;

    struct lfs_lookahead {
        lfs_block_t start;
        lfs_block_t size;
        lfs_block_t next;
        lfs_block_t ckpoint;
        uint8_t *buffer;
    } lookahead;

    const struct lfs_config *cfg;
    lfs_size_t block_count;
    lfs_size_t name_max;
    lfs_size_t file_max;
    lfs_size_t attr_max;
    lfs_size_t inline_max;

#ifdef LFS_MIGRATE
    struct lfs1 *lfs1;
#endif
} lfs_t
...
typedef struct lfs_dir {
    struct lfs_dir *next;
    uint16_t id;
    uint8_t type;
    lfs_mdir_t m;

    lfs_off_t pos;
    lfs_block_t head[2];
} lfs_dir_t
...
struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    }
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected all provided code fragments: lfs_dir_close, lfs_dir_close_, lfs_mlist_remove, the related macros (LFS_LOCK, LFS_UNLOCK, LFS_TRACE), and the type/struct definitions. There is no use of the Standard Library function memcmp anywhere in the supplied code. There are no string comparisons (no strcmp/strncmp/memcmp calls), no inclusion of string.h shown, and the only comparisons present are pointer equality checks (e.g. if (*p == mlist) in lfs_mlist_remove) which do not involve comparing null-terminated strings. Therefore there are no code fragments here that should be investigated for violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14.
